description: From Middle English syne, syn, sin, a contracted form of sithen (“since”). More at sithen.

adverbs.description: syne (comparative more syne, superlative most syne)

examples: At last he comes, and on his knee
An' ilk yen strives to catch his ee,
Syne tugs his cwoat an' bids him sing.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, Northern England, chiefly in phrases like "soon as syne") Late.
examples: [Each rogue] shall be discovered either soon or syne.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, Northern England) Before now; ago. [from 16th c.]
examples: I eat, drink, and sleep as sound as I did twenty years syne; yes, I laugh heartily too, and find as many subjects to employ that faculty upon as ever; fools, fops, and knaves, grow as rank as formerly, yet here and there,  […]
I've niver set fute i' Gibb's Ha' syne his father's death.
